description: 1490, from Middle French mignon (“lover, royal favourite, darling”), from Old French mignon (“dainty, pleasing, gentle, kind”), from Frankish *minnju (“love, friendship, affection, memory”), from Proto-Germanic *minþijō, *mindijō (“affectionate thought, care”), from Proto-Indo-European *men- (“to think”).

adjectives.description: minion (comparative more minion, superlative most minion)

entries.meaning: A loyal servant of another, usually a more powerful being.
examples: Synonyms: disciple, follower; see also Thesaurus:loyal follower

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A loved one; one highly esteemed and favoured.
examples: God's disciple and his dearest minion

entries.meaning: (obsolete) An ancient form of ordnance with a calibre of about three inches.
(uncountable, typography, printing) The size of type between nonpareil and brevier, standardized as 7-point.

examples: Of philosophers and scholars priscae sapientiae dictatores, I have already spoken in general terms, those superintendents of wit and learning, men above men, those refined men, minions of the muses.
